attributes.title: How Can I Study the Sun?
Secrets of the Sun Preview
attributes.description_short: Scientists are striving to better grasp our star and its destructive solar storms.
attributes.description_long: It contains 99.9 percent of all the matter in our solar system and sheds hot plasma at nearly a million miles an hour. The temperature at its core is a staggering 27 million degrees Fahrenheit. It convulses, it blazes, it sings. You know it as the sun. Scientists know it as one of the most amazing physics laboratories in the universe.
attributes.player_code: <iframe  id='partnerPlayer' frameborder='0' marginwidth='0' marginheight='0' scrolling='no' width='100%' height='100%' src='//player.pbs.org/partnerplayer/x1WpZWt7jx0bClFqhkBZxA==/?topbar=false&end=0&endscreen=true&start=0&autoplay=false' allowfullscreen></iframe>

attributes.title: New Ways to Catch the Rays
Secrets of the Sun
attributes.description_short: New tools let scientists better grasp our star's potentially destructive solar storms.
attributes.description_long: It contains 99.9 percent of all the matter in our solar system and sheds hot plasma at nearly a million miles an hour. The temperature at its core is a staggering 27 million degrees Fahrenheit. It convulses, it blazes, it sings. You know it as the sun. Scientists know it as one of the most amazing physics laboratories in the universe.
